context.text: Apart from [11], previous work in this area has assumed a sensor detection performance which is approximately constant.

While there is a well-developed base of literature covering track confirmation and termination for sensors with a fixed \$P_{{\rm D}}\$ of the target on a single scan, research pertaining to the track management problem for sensors with k \$P_{{\rm D}}\$ on a Markov model has only recently been considered [11].

While the optimality of centralized approaches to data fusion is well known [3], [7], it has been shown [11] that when a target detection model accounting for the fading detection performance of the sensors is used, improved performance was achieved using a decentralized tracking approach when the same track confirmation rule was applied.

In order to more accurately model the sensor performance as it is observed during at-sea testing, a two-state Markov chain detection model is used to describe a sensor's probability of detection \$(P_D)\$ of the target in a single scan, similar to that used in [11] except that state transition probabilities are given in terms of a discrete time model rather than in continuous time.

This supports the result from [11] which showed that a track confirmation rule that differentiates measurements by sensor origin can outperform a rule that does not differentiate measurements by sensor origin when each sensor's \$P_{\rm D}\$ is subject to an underlying Markov detection process.

Next, multiples are distributed to the reduction stage through multiplexers controlled by the BCD multiplier digits ([0], [9]).
An example of this architecture, implemented in a decimal parallel multiplier, can be found in [9].
The other two 16-digit decimal fixed-point parallel multipliers analyzed are detailed in [9], [20].
A variant of this multiplier proposed in [9] uses a configuration of full adders [8] to perform the partial product reduction.
The latency values given by the authors for the combinational designs are 2.51 ns (55.8 FO4) [9] and 2.65 ns (58.9 FO4) [20].
We observe that the SD radix-5 decimal multiplier has a maximum speedup of 1.20 with respect to [9] using at most 0.70 time its area.
On the other hand, the SD radix-10 multiplier is 1.15 times faster and 0.65 time smaller than the design proposed in [9].

context.text: Due to its low complexity, the AF relaying strategy is of especial interest [12]–[14][18].
However, with available CSI, distributed network beamforming can provide better performance [14], [15].
Recently, several distributed AF beamforming techniques for relay networks with flat fading channels have been developed [14]–[18].

The approaches of [14]–[16] optimize the receiver quality-of-service (QoS) subject to the individual and/or total power constraints under the assumption that the instantaneous CSI is perfectly known at the destination or relay nodes.
In particular, all the techniques of [14]–[18] [19] assume the transmitter-to-relay and relay-to-destination channels to be frequency flat.

In the latter case, there is a significant amount of intersymbol interference (ISI) which makes it difficult to directly extend the techniques of [14]–[18] [19] to frequency selective fading channel scenarios.

Similar to the techniques of [14]–[18], the receiver is assumed to use a perfect source-to-relay and relay-to-destination CSI to compute the relay weight coefficients and feed them back to the relay nodes using a low-rate receiver-to-relays feedback link.

As in the frequency selective case the major performance limiting factor is ISI rather than noise, the QoS is measured in terms of the receiver signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR), in contrast to the techniques of [14]–[16] [17] that use the SNR as a measure of QoS in the flat fading case.
It is shown that in the flat fading case, the proposed FF network beamforming techniques reduce to the AF network beamformers of [14]–[16] [17] which are particular cases of our techniques.
Similar to [14] and [16]–[18], it is assumed that there is no direct link between the transmitter and destination nodes and that the network is perfectly synchronized.
Note that quite similar assumptions have been used in [14]–[18] in the frequency flat fading case.

For ceramic magnets, the Curie temperature is lower than the temperature at which significant metallurgical changes occur, and it is the other way around for Alnico, SmCo, and NdFeB magnets [2]–[3], [10].

It follows the relative recoil permeability line, which is the dotted line \$a^{\prime\prime}-b^{\prime}-b-B_{r}^{\prime}\$ line) in Fig. 1(a), and recovers to \$b\$ ‘ under normal load conditions resulting in irreversible demagnetization [2]–[3], [13].
If the temperature decreases to \$T_{1}\$, the operating point is formed on the \$a^{\prime\prime}-B_{r}^{\prime}\$ recoil line resulting in irreversible demagnetization [2]–[3].
Rare-earth magnet materials are susceptible to metallurgical structure changes due to corrosion or oxidation, and this also results in demagnetization [2]–[3], [10], [14]–[16].

Other possible causes of demagnetization include gradual decrease in magnet strength (domain relaxation [3]) and damage (chipping, cracking, etc …) due to vibration, shock, or mechanical forces during operation.

Section IV states and proves a key result of this paper: For convex and strictly increasing error functions, the sufficient conditions given by Trushkin [24] for the uniqueness of a locally optimal fixed-rate scalar quantizer are also sufficient for the uniqueness of a locally optimal fixed-rate convex \$K\$-DSQ, with respect to a given IA.

As shown by Trushkin [24], for every \$V\leq a< b\leq W\$, the function \$D_{a,b}(y)=\int_{a}^{b}f(\vert x-y\vert)p(x)dx\$, defined for every \$y\in [V,W]\$, achieves its minimum in some unique point \$\mu (a,b)\$, situated inside the interval \$(a,b)\$.
Sufficient conditions for the global optimality of a locally optimal fixed-rate scalar quantizer were investigated in [11], [18], [19], [24], [25].

Trushkin considered a more general distortion measure, namely, \$d(x,y)=g(x,\vert x-y\vert)\$, such that \$g(x,\eta)\$ is convex in \$\eta\$, has a unique zero point for each \$x\$ and is continuous in \$x\$ [24].
To the best of our knowledge, the conditions formulated by Trushkin in [24] have been the most general sufficient conditions for uniqueness of local optimal scalar quantizer so far.
The next theorem states that under the same conditions for \$p(x)\$ as in [24, Theorem 1], there is at most one locally optimal \$K\$-DSQ of a given IA.

Because the function \$\mu (\cdot, \cdot)\$ is nondecreasing in both variables [24], \$x_{1}< x_{0}\$ and \$z_{0}< z_{1}\$ imply that \$\mu (x_{0},z_{0})\geq \mu (x_{1},z_{0})\$ and \$\mu (x_{1},z_{0})\leq \mu (x_{1},z_{1})\$.

If Conditions A and B hold, \${\mmb Q}\$ is a locally optimal convex \$K\$-DSQ, its IA is optimal, and the conditions in Theorem 1 are satisfied (e.g., if \$p(x)\$ is log-concave and the error function is the squared difference [24, Theorem 4]), then \${\mmb Q}\$ is a globally optimal convex \$K\$-DSQ.

context.text: The analysis given here complements our earlier paper [31] that established precise thresholds on the success/failure of the Lasso (i.e., \$\ell_1\$-constrained quadratic programming) for sparsity recovery.

Most directly related to this paper are results, applicable to \$\ell_1\$-constrained quadratic programming or the Lasso, that provide sufficient conditions [22], [36], [31] or necessary conditions [31] on the amount of data required for subset recovery (i.e., with the error metric (3)).

These results isolate a mutual incoherence property [17], [29] of the design matrix that must be satisfied for the Lasso to succeed in recovering the support, and the paper [31] provides sharp scalings on \$({n}, {p}, k)\$ that demarcate the boundary between success and failure.

In covering the full range of scaling, the results given here are complementary to those of our previous paper [31] that provided threshold results, also applicable to general scaling of \$({n}, {p}, {k})\$, for the success/failure of the Lasso when used for sparsity recovery with general Gaussian measurement ensembles.

For random design matrices \${X}\$ drawn from any \${\Sigma}\$-Gaussian ensemble satisfying a certain mutual incoherence condition (see (25) to follow), Wainwright [31] establishes a sharp phase transition for the success/failure of the Lasso.

If we assume that \${\lambda_{\min}}({\Sigma}_{S S})\$ and the incoherence parameter remain bounded away from \$({p}, k)\$, the Lasso threshold [31] is of the form for constants \${c_1}, {c_1}' > 0\$.

Regardless of the linear fraction \${\alpha}\$ and the squared minimum \${\beta^2_{\min}}\$, success of the Lasso for support recovery [31] requires the number \${n}\$ of samples to scale so quickly such that \${n}/{p} \rightarrow +\infty\$.

Indeed, a consequence of the results of Wainwright [31] is that the Lasso requires \${n} \asymp k \log({p} - k)\$ samples to perform support recovery, which scales much more rapidly than \$k \log({p}/k)\$ in the case of linear sparsity.
It was first defined in the context of sample design matrices independently by Fuchs [17] and Tropp [29], and also imposed in other high-dimensional analysis of the Lasso [22], [36], [31].

It is known [36], [31] that if the Lasso is applied to any ensemble of \${\Sigma}\$-Gaussian measurement matrices for which the incoherence assumption (25) is violated and the noise \$w\$ has a symmetric distribution, it will fail with probability at least \$1/2\$, regardless of the sample size (see Wainwright [31] for a precise statement).

Consequently, for this ensemble and for any subset with \$k > 2 \sqrt{{p}}\$ elements that excludes the index \$\{1\}\$, the probability of incorrect support recovery using \$\ell_1\$-constrained quadratic programming is at least one half [31], regardless of the sample size, whereas the optimal decoder will succeed with high probability for sample sizes \${n} > {\bar{n}_{S}}\$.\$\hfill\diamondsuit\$.

In conjunction with previous work [31] on the limits of the Lasso (\$\ell_1\$-constrained quadratic programming), this analysis has some consequences.

(a)For signals \${\beta^*}\$ of bounded norm, the Lasso achieves the information-theoretically optimal order of scaling as a function of \$({n}, {p}, k)\$ and \${\beta^2_{\min}}\$ (see Corollary 1), whereas
(b)for signals \${\beta^*}\$ with linear sparsity \$(k = {\alpha} {p})\$ and squared minimum value \${\beta^2_{\min}} = \Theta({\log k\over k})\$, the Lasso is suboptimal (see Corollary 2).

This observation provides a fundamental justification for the approach of [7].
In [7], the network is modeled as an operator channel that takes in a subspace \${\cal V} \in {\cal P}_q(m)\$ and puts out a possibly different subspace \${\cal U} \in {\cal P}_q(m)\$.
Thus, the difference between the approach of this section and that of [7] lies in the choice of the decoder.
The subspace metric of [7] treats insertions and deletions of dimensions (called in [7] “errors” and “erasures,” respectively) symmetrically.

However, depending upon the position of the adversary in the network (namely, if there is a source–destination min-cut between the adversary and the destination) then a single error packet may cause the replacement of a dimension (i.e., a simultaneous “error” and “erasure” in the terminology of [7]).

If it were possible to restrict the adversary so that each error-packet injection would only cause either an insertion or a deletion of a dimension (but not both), then the subspace distance of [7] would indeed be appropriate.
In other words, in this special case, the approach in [7] coincides with that of this paper, and Theorem 20 provides a converse that was missing in [7].
